Value and Risk in Energy Markets















Value and Risk in Energy Markets 
		- Introduction To Principles and Methods


      	Program: Value and Risk in Energy Markets

June 19-21, 2007 - Loews Coronado Bay Resort & Spa  - San Diego, CA
Click
        Here To Download A Complete Conference Brochure











Background:

This course introduces principles and methods of 
market-based valuation and risk management. Familiarity with these principles 
and methods is now essential to managing all of the major resources and 
commitments in the electric power industry, including fuel and power purchase 
contracts, generation resources, retail service agreements, and regulatory 
policies (e.g., Provider of Last Resort obligations). Participants will study 
the financial "building blocks" -- elementary forward and option contracts. 
Trainers will explain how the value and risk of non-financial contracts and 
physical assets can be understood in terms of equivalent combinations of 
elementary contracts. With these principles, participants will study methods for 
valuing forward contracts and options, both simple and complex; modeling 
uncertainty in market prices; and estimating volatility. Finally, participants 
will learn about the basic risk management strategies, as well as how to 
calculate risk exposures and measure portfolio risk.

Register today!



Workshop Outline:


The course addresses concepts, instruments, and methods for measuring 
		and managing risk in energy commodity markets. A series of exercises 
		will be included to reinforce the main ideas.
		Topics include:
. Basic forward and option contracts
		. Relationship of complex contracts and physical assets to basic 
		contracts
		. Valuing forward contracts and estimating forward prices
		. Valuing simple option contracts
		. Modeling price uncertainty and estimating volatility
		. Methods for valuing complex options
		. Basic risk management strategies
		. Measuring and managing portfolio risk
		 



Who Should Attend:



This course should be of interest to staff with responsibilities in the 
following areas:
. Power and fuel procurement
. Generation planning
. Retail services
. Regulatory policy
. Energy trading and marketing
. Treasury and corporate finance
. Corporate strategy
Class size will be limited to 25 attendees on a first-come, first-serve 
basis. This is an intensive, skill-building class in which participants will 
work through numerous examples with the aid of paper, pencil, and hand-held 
calculators.

Prior training in financial economics is NOT required. The Value & Risk in 
Energy Markets workshop begins at 8:30 a.m. on day one and concludes at noon on 
day three.



Course Instructor:



Art Altman
Program Manager, EPRI's Value & Risk in Energy Markets
Art's background is in finance and information technology, and his focus at 
EPRI is on R&D in risk management and asset valuation. He helps EPRI member 
companies value contracts and assets and manage the financial risks that they 
face in competitive power
markets. Art is currently the manager of EPRI's Energy Book System, an 
integrated suite of software tools for valuation and risk management. He has an 
M.B.A. from the University of California at Berkeley, and an M.S. from the 
University of Rochester. Email: aaltman@epri.com
